title: 30-Minute Sausage Tortellini Soup

description: This hearty and comforting sausage tortellini soup is a family favorite that comes together in just 30 minutes. Packed with flavor and wholesome ingredients, it's perfect for busy weeknights when you crave something warm and satisfying.
instructions: In a large pot, cook the Italian sausage over medium heat until browned, breaking it apart with a spoon.
Add the chopped onion and minced garlic, cooking until the onion is translucent.
Pour in the chicken broth and diced tomatoes, bringing the mixture to a boil.
Stir in the tortellini and cook according to package instructions until tender.
Add the fresh spinach and cook until wilted, about 2 minutes.
Season with salt and pepper to taste, and serve hot with grated Parmesan cheese on top.
tips: For a richer flavor, try using homemade broth and adding a pinch of red pepper flakes for a little heat.

structured_content.content:
Sausage tortellini soup is basically the perfect weeknight dinner. Takes 30 minutes and tastes like you spent way longer making it. I throw this together all the time when I need something fast that actually fills everyone up. The sausage makes it hearty and the tortellini makes it feel special.

First time I made this was on a crazy Tuesday when I had nothing planned for dinner. Found some sausage and a bag of frozen tortellini in the freezer. Just dumped everything in a pot and hoped for the best. Turned out so good that now it's on regular rotation at our house.

note.label: Why This Works
note.content:
• Done in 30 minutes which is about as fast as it gets
  • Tastes way better than the effort you put in
  • Perfect for those nights when everyone needs real food quick
  • Everything you need is basic grocery store stuff
  • Actually freezes well so you can make extra

structured_content.content: My kids love this soup. They usually pick at their food but they actually eat this without me asking them 50 times. I think it's the tortellini. Makes them feel like they're eating something fun instead of just regular soup. Whatever works, right?

This is one of those soups that saves you on busy nights. Like when you have back to back stuff happening and dinner almost doesn't happen. Quick, warm, filling. Checks all the boxes for what you need when life gets hectic.

• Italian sausage: Get the kind in the tube or links, whatever's easier. I usually go for mild because my kids can't handle spicy. Hot sausage works if you like heat though.
  • Tortellini: Frozen or refrigerated both work fine. Cheese filled is classic but you could try other kinds. Just read the package for cooking time.
  • Spinach: Fresh is better but honestly frozen works too. Just squeeze out the extra water first. Adds some green vegetables so you don't feel guilty.
  • Chicken broth: Store bought is totally fine. I keep boxes in the pantry all the time. Makes everything taste better than water.
  • A big pot: Needs to fit everything without overflowing. I use my dutch oven but any big soup pot works.

Don't stress if you're missing something. Soup is pretty forgiving. No spinach? Leave it out or use kale. Don't have canned tomatoes? Use marinara sauce. I've made this a hundred different ways depending on what was in the fridge. Always turns out fine.

upload.context: A vibrant display of fresh ingredients ready for the soup preparation.

structured_content.content:
Getting started:
If you're using links, squeeze the sausage out of the casings. Chop your onion and garlic. Get everything ready before you start cooking because it moves pretty fast once you begin.
Cooking it:
Brown the sausage in your pot. Break it up with a spoon while it cooks. Add the onion and garlic and cook until the onion gets soft. Pour in the broth and tomatoes and let it boil. Throw in the tortellini and cook until they're done. Toss in the spinach at the end and let it wilt. Season it and you're done.
Serving it:
Put it in bowls and top with Parmesan cheese. That's it. Easy.

The main thing is not to overcook the tortellini. They get mushy if you leave them in too long. Just follow whatever the package says for cooking time. I set a timer because I always forget and walk away. Mushy tortellini isn't great but it's still edible if you mess up.

upload.context: Capturing the cooking process of the soup simmering in the pot.

note.label: Don't Forget
note.content:
• Brown the sausage completely before adding other stuff. Raw sausage is gross.
  • Don't cook the tortellini forever or they turn to mush.
  • When the spinach wilts down it's ready. Takes like 2 minutes.
  • Keeps in the fridge for 3 days. Reheat on the stove or microwave.
  • The tortellini soak up liquid when stored so add more broth when reheating.

structured_content.content: We eat this soup probably twice a month during winter. It's one of those comfort food things that everyone likes. My husband always has seconds. Sometimes I make a double batch just so we have leftovers for lunch the next day.

Leftover soup is great because it's already done. Just heat it up and eat. The tortellini soak up the broth overnight so sometimes I add a splash of water or more broth when I reheat it. Still tastes good though. Maybe even better after sitting.

Heavy cream makes it richer if you want that. Pour in like half a cup at the end. Turns it into a creamy soup instead of broth based. My husband likes it this way but I usually skip it to keep it lighter.

Red pepper flakes add nice heat. Just sprinkle some in when you add the broth. Start with a little and taste it. You can always add more but you can't take it out. I keep a jar on the table for people who want extra spice.
Fresh herbs at the end are good. Basil or parsley, whatever you have. Makes it smell amazing and taste fresher. I don't always have fresh herbs around but when I do it's worth adding them.

Crusty bread is perfect for dipping. I usually buy a loaf from the bakery section and warm it up. Garlic bread works too if you want to go that route. Good for soaking up all the broth at the bottom of your bowl.
A simple salad makes it feel like a complete meal. Nothing fancy, just greens with whatever dressing you like. Balances out the heavy soup. Plus vegetables are good for you or whatever.

Sometimes I just eat the soup by itself with crackers. Saltines or those fancy crackers, doesn't matter. Easy side that doesn't require any work. Perfect for lazy nights when you barely want to cook at all.

Turkey sausage works if you want something lighter. Tastes a little different but still good. My friend uses it all the time and says her family likes it just as much. Less greasy than regular sausage.

For vegetarian people, skip the sausage and add more vegetables. Mushrooms, zucchini, bell peppers, whatever. Use vegetable broth instead of chicken broth. Won't taste exactly the same but it'll still be good soup.

Whole wheat tortellini if you're trying to be healthy. I've used it before and you can't really tell the difference once it's in the soup. Same with using turkey sausage. Makes you feel better about eating a big bowl of pasta.

upload.context: A beautifully plated bowl of sausage tortellini soup ready to be enjoyed.

note.label: Extra Stuff
note.content:
• Really brown the sausage good. That's where a lot of the flavor comes from.
  • Chop everything before you start so you're not scrambling while cooking.
  • Watch the tortellini close. They go from perfect to mushy fast.
  • Parmesan cheese on top makes it look nicer and taste better.
  • Fresh herbs if you have them really do help.

structured_content.content: This soup freezes pretty well if you want to make a big batch. Let it cool completely first. Put it in containers or freezer bags. Good for like 2 months in the freezer. The tortellini texture changes a tiny bit but it's not a big deal. Thaw it in the fridge overnight and reheat on the stove.

For super fast cooking, use pre-cooked sausage. Those crumbles they sell already cooked. Just heat them up with the onions and skip the browning step. Saves maybe 5 minutes. Not quite as good but when you're really rushed it works fine.

Sausage tortellini soup is one of those recipes everyone should know how to make. It's fast, easy, and tastes homemade even though it's basically just throwing stuff in a pot. Perfect for busy families who still want real food on the table.

Try it out next time you need a quick dinner. Make it exactly like this or change it up however you want. The whole point is easy comfort food that doesn't take forever. That's what weeknight cooking should be.
